{{DEFAULTSORT:Woodroof, Ron}}
{{Infobox person | name = Ron Woodroof | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_date = 1950 | birth_place = Texas | death_date = Sept. 12, 1992 | death_place = | occupation = | spouse = | parents = | children = }}
'''Ron Woodroof''' created what would become known as the Dallas Buyers Club in March 1988. Contracting HIV in the 1980s, he created the group as part of his efforts to find and distribute drugs to treat [[HIV]] at a time when the disease was poorly understood.<ref>http://www.biography.com/people/ron-woodroof-21329541#early-years&</ref>
He sued the FDA over a ban on a drug he was using. <ref name="npr">http://www.npr.org/2013/11/01/242309799/the-dallas-cowboy-behind-the-real-buyers-club</ref>
He died on September 12, 1992. <ref name="npr"></ref>
==Biography==
He had a mercurial personality. One reporter writes that "Woodroof took guns to his doctor’s office, prompting Dr. Steven Pounders to 'fire him as a patient.'". Woodroof later sent the doctor roses and the doctor took him back as a patient.<ref>http://www.dallasnews.com/entertainment/movies/headlines/20131101-the-real-story-behind-the-dallas-buyers-club-movie.ece</ref>
Some of his friends have told reporters he was gay or bisexual.<ref>http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/02/06/ron-woodroof-gay-dallas-buyers-club_n_4740155.html</ref><ref>http://www.slate.com/blogs/browbeat/2014/01/17/was_dallas_buyers_club_s_ron_woodroof_gay_or_bisexual_friends_and_doctor.html</ref>
===Death and afterward===
His life was the basis of the 2013 film ''[[The Dallas Buyers Club]].''

{{DEFAULTSORT:Woodroof, Ron}} {{Infobox person | name = Ron Woodroof | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_date = {{Birth date|1950|2|3}} | birth_place = Texas | death_date = {{Death date and age|1992|9|12|1950|2|3}} | death_place = | occupation = | spouse = | parents = | children = }} '''Ronald Dickson "Ron" Woodroof''' (3 February 1950 - 12 September 1992) was an American who created what would become known as the Dallas Buyers Club in March 1988. Contracting HIV in the 1980s, he created the group as part of his efforts to find and distribute drugs to treat [[HIV]] at a time when the disease was poorly understood.<ref>[http://www.biography.com/people/ron-woodroof-21329541 Ron Woodroof] The Biography.com website. Retrieved 2014-07-09</ref>
He sued the [[Food and Drug Administration|FDA]] over a ban on a drug he was using.<ref name="npr">{{cite web|url=http://www.npr.org/2013/11/01/242309799/the-dallas-cowboy-behind-the-real-buyers-club |title=The Dallas Cowboy Behind The Real 'Buyers Club' |publisher=NPR |date=2013-11-01 |accessdate=2014-07-09}}</ref>
==Biography==
He had a mercurial personality. One reporter writes that "Woodroof took guns to his doctor’s office, prompting Dr. Steven Pounders to 'fire him as a patient.'". Woodroof later sent the doctor roses and the doctor took him back as a patient.<ref name="dallasnews">{{cite web|last=Jacobson |first=Sherry |url=http://www.dallasnews.com/entertainment/movies/headlines/20131101-the-real-story-behind-the-dallas-buyers-club-movie.ece |title=The real story behind the ‘Dallas Buyers Club’ movie | Dallas Morning News |publisher=Dallasnews.com |date= |accessdate=2014-07-09}}</ref>
Some of his friends have told reporters he was gay or bisexual.<ref>{{cite web|author=Posted: 02/06/2014 3:24 pm EST |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/02/06/ron-woodroof-gay-dallas-buyers-club_n_4740155.html |title=The Real Ron Woodroof 'Had Relationships With Gay Men,' Says A Friend Of The 'Dallas Buyers Club' Subject |publisher=Huffingtonpost.com |date= |accessdate=2014-07-09}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Wickman |first=Forrest |url=http://www.slate.com/blogs/browbeat/2014/01/17/was_dallas_buyers_club_s_ron_woodroof_gay_or_bisexual_friends_and_doctor.html |title=Was Dallas Buyers Club’s Ron Woodroof gay or bisexual? Friends and doctor say maybe, so why did the movie make him straight? |publisher=Slate.com |date=2014-01-17 |accessdate=2014-07-09}}</ref>
Accounts differ on whether he made homophobic comments. Reporter and screenwriter [[Craig Borten]] has said Woodroof was "as racist and homophobic as they come" while friends reportedly claim the opposite.<ref name="dallasnews"></ref>
== Death and afterward == Seven years following his diagnosis of HIV, Ron Woodroof died on September 12, 1992 from [[pneumonia]] brought on by AIDS. <!-- let's keep the information on the film to a minimum, since this article is supposed to be about the individual, not the movie --> Over 20 years following his death, Woodroof's final years became the basis of the 2013 film ''[[Dallas Buyers Club]].'' He was portrayed in the film by [[Matthew McConaughey]], who won many awards from his role including the [[Academy Award for Best Actor]]. <ref>{{cite web|title='We can't even look at him': Family of real-life AIDS victim played by Matthew McConaughey in harrowing new movie reveal the TRUE story of courage that inspired actor's 'breathtaking' transformation|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2244249/Pictured-Real-life-AIDs-victim-Ron-Woodroof-tragic-life-played-Matthew-McConaughey-movie-The-Dallas-Club.html|work=[[Daily Mail]]|accessdate=August 18, 2014|date=December 6, 2012}}</ref>

They were divorced on March 23, 1972 in [[Dallas]], [[Texas]]. Shortly after their divorce, he married Rory S. Flynn on May 6, 1972 in [[Dallas]], [[Texas]]. However, they were divorced on May 21, 1973 in [[Dallas]], [[Texas]]. He remarried Brenda Shari Robin on October 4, 1982 in [[Lubbock, Texas|Lubbock]], [[Texas]]. However, they were finally divorced on March 4, 1986 in [[Dallas]], [[Texas]] after he was diagnosed with [[Human immunodeficiency virus|HIV]]. He had a mercurial personality. One reporter writes that "Woodroof took guns to his doctor’s office, prompting Dr. Steven Pounders to 'fire him as a patient.'" Contracting the human immunodeficiency virus ([[HIV]]) in the 1980s, he created the group as part of his efforts to find and distribute drugs to treat HIV at a time when the disease was poorly understood.[http://www.biography.com/people/ron-woodroof-21329541 Ron Woodroof] The Biography.com website. Retrieved 2014-07-09 He sued the United States [[Food and Drug Administration]] (FDA) over a ban on a drug he was using.{{cite web|url=http://www.npr.org/2013/11/01/242309799/the-dallas-cowboy-behind-the-real-buyers-club |title=The Dallas Cowboy Behind The Real 'Buyers Club' |publisher=NPR |date=2013-11-01 |accessdate=2014-07-09}} ==Biography== Ron Woodroof was born in [[Dallas]], [[Texas]], on February 3, 1950 to Garland Odell Woodroof (March 17, 1917 in Texas - December 3, 1983 in Dallas, Texas) and Willie Mae Hughes (November 25, 1917 in [[Oklahoma]] - November 19, 1996 in Dallas, Texas).1940 United States Census: District 255-224, Family Number 207, Sheet Number and Letter 8A His first marriage was to Mary Etta Pybus on June 28, 1969 in Dallas, Texas, and they had a daughter, Yvette Lynn Woodroof (born February 1, 1970 in Dallas, Texas). They divorced on March 23, 1972 in Dallas, Texas. On May 6, 1972 he married Rory S. Flynn in Dallas, Texas. They divorced on May 21, 1973 in Dallas, Texas. He then married Brenda Shari Robin on October 4, 1982 in [[Lubbock, Texas|Lubbock]], Texas. They divorced on March 4, 1986 in Dallas, Texas after he was diagnosed with HIV. He had a mercurial personality. One reporter writes that "Woodroof took guns to his doctor’s office, prompting Dr. Steven Pounders to 'fire him as a patient.'" Woodroof later sent the doctor roses and the doctor took him back.{{cite web|last=Jacobson |first=Sherry |url=http://www.dallasnews.com/entertainment/movies/headlines/20131101-the-real-story-behind-the-dallas-buyers-club-movie.ece |title=The real story behind the ‘Dallas Buyers Club’ movie | Dallas Morning News |publisher=Dallasnews.com |date= |accessdate=2014-07-09}} Some of his friends told reporters he was gay or bisexual.{{cite web|author=Posted: 02/06/2014 3:24 pm EST |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/02/06/ron-woodroof-gay-dallas-buyers-club_n_4740155.html |title=The Real Ron Woodroof 'Had Relationships With Gay Men,' Says A Friend Of The 'Dallas Buyers Club' Subject |publisher=Huffingtonpost.com |date= |accessdate=2014-07-09}}{{cite web|last=Wickman |first=Forrest |url=http://www.slate.com/blogs/browbeat/2014/01/17/was_dallas_buyers_club_s_ron_woodroof_gay_or_bisexual_friends_and_doctor.html |title=Was Dallas Buyers Club’s Ron Woodroof gay or bisexual? Friends and doctor say maybe, so why did the movie make him straight? |publisher=Slate.com |date=2014-01-17 |accessdate=2014-07-09}} Accounts differ on whether he made homophobic comments. Reporter and screenwriter [[Craig Borten]] has said Woodroof was "as racist and homophobic as they come" while friends reportedly claim the opposite. According to Borten, although Woodroof did not have a Rayon in his life (as in the film) he was a changed man following his diagnosis and his work with the Dallas Buyers Club. In fact he transformed from a Homophobe to a compassionate advocate. www.slate.com/How Accurate is Dallas Buyers Club? By Aisha Harris == Death and afterward == Seven years following his diagnosis of HIV, Ron Woodroof died on September 12, 1992 from [[pneumonia]] brought on by AIDS. Over 20 years following his death, Woodroof's final years became the basis of the 2013 film ''[[Dallas Buyers Club]].'' He was portrayed in the film by [[Matthew McConaughey]], who won many awards for his performance, including the [[Academy Award for Best Actor]]. {{cite web|title='We can't even look at him': Family of real-life AIDS victim played by Matthew McConaughey in harrowing new movie reveal the TRUE story of courage that inspired actor's 'breathtaking' transformation|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2244249/Pictured-Real-life-AIDs-victim-Ron-Woodroof-tragic-life-played-Matthew-McConaughey-movie-The-Dallas-Club.html|work=[[Daily Mail]]|accessdate=August 18, 2014|date=December 6, 2012}} ==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:1950 births]] [[Category:1992 deaths]] [[Category:AIDS-related deaths in Texas]] [[Category:HIV/AIDS activists]] [[Category:American electricians]] [[Category:People from Dallas, Texas]]

Willie Mae Hughes (1917-1996)Social Security Death Index Number 465-18-1334 | children = }} '''Ronald Dickson "Ron" Woodroof''' (February 3, 1950 – September 12, 1992) was an American who created what would become known as the Dallas Buyers Club in March 1988. Contracting the human immunodeficiency virus ([[HIV]]) in the 1980s, he created the group as part of his efforts to find and distribute drugs to treat HIV at a time when the disease was poorly understood.[http://www.biography.com/people/ron-woodroof-21329541 Ron Woodroof] The Biography.com website. Retrieved 2014-07-09 He sued the United States [[Food and Drug Administration]] (FDA) over a ban on a drug he was using.{{cite web|url=http://www.npr.org/2013/11/01/242309799/the-dallas-cowboy-behind-the-real-buyers-club |title=The Dallas Cowboy Behind The Real 'Buyers Club' |publisher=NPR |date=2013-11-01 |accessdate=2014-07-09}} ==Biography== Ron Woodroof was born in [[Dallas]], [[Texas]], on February 3, 1950, to Garland Odell Woodroof (March 17, 1917, in Texas - December 3, 1983, in Dallas) and Willie Mae Hughes (November 25, 1917, in [[Oklahoma]] - November 19, 1996, in Dallas).1940 United States Census: District 255-224, Family Number 207, Sheet Number and Letter 8A His first marriage was to Mary Etta Pybus on June 28, 1969, in Dallas; and they had a daughter Yvette Lynn Woodroof (born February 1, 1970). They divorced on March 23, 1972. On May 6, 1972, he married Rory S. Flynn in Dallas. They divorced on May 21, 1973. He then married Brenda Shari Robin on October 4, 1982, in [[Lubbock, Texas|Lubbock]]. They divorced on March 4, 1986, after he was diagnosed with HIV. He had a mercurial personality. One reporter writes that "Woodroof took guns to his doctor’s office, prompting Dr. Steven Pounders to 'fire him as a patient.'" Woodroof later sent the doctor roses, and the doctor took him back.{{cite web|last=Jacobson |first=Sherry |url=http://www.dallasnews.com/entertainment/movies/headlines/20131101-the-real-story-behind-the-dallas-buyers-club-movie.ece |title=The real story behind the ‘Dallas Buyers Club’ movie | Dallas Morning News |publisher=Dallasnews.com |date= |accessdate=2014-07-09}} Some of his friends told reporters he was [[gay]] or [[bisexual]].{{cite web|author=Posted: 02/06/2014 3:24 pm EST |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/02/06/ron-woodroof-gay-dallas-buyers-club_n_4740155.html |title=The Real Ron Woodroof 'Had Relationships With Gay Men,' Says A Friend Of The 'Dallas Buyers Club' Subject |publisher=Huffingtonpost.com |date= |accessdate=2014-07-09}}{{cite web|last=Wickman |first=Forrest |url=http://www.slate.com/blogs/browbeat/2014/01/17/was_dallas_buyers_club_s_ron_woodroof_gay_or_bisexual_friends_and_doctor.html |title=Was Dallas Buyers Club’s Ron Woodroof gay or bisexual? Friends and doctor say maybe, so why did the movie make him straight? |publisher=Slate.com |date=2014-01-17 |accessdate=2014-07-09}} Accounts differ on whether he made [[homophobic]] comments. Reporter and screenwriter [[Craig Borten]] has said Woodroof was "as [[racist]] and homophobic as they come" while friends reportedly claim the opposite. According to Borten, although Woodroof did not have a Rayon in his life (as in the film) he was a changed man following his diagnosis and his work with the Dallas Buyers Club. == Death and afterward == Seven years following his diagnosis of HIV, Ron Woodroof died on September 12, 1992 from [[pneumonia]] brought on by AIDS. Over 20 years following his death, Woodroof's final years became the basis of the 2013 film ''[[Dallas Buyers Club]].'' Willie Mae Hughes (1917-1996)Social Security Death Index Number 465-18-1334 | children = }} '''Ronald Dickson "Ron" Woodroof''' (February 3, 1950 – September 12, 1992) was an American man who created what would become known as the Dallas Buyers Club in March 1988. After contracting the human immunodeficiency virus ([[HIV]]) in the 1980s, he created the group as part of his efforts to find and distribute drugs to treat HIV at a time when the disease was poorly understood.[http://www.biography.com/people/ron-woodroof-21329541 Ron Woodroof] The Biography.com website. Retrieved 2014-07-09 He sued the United States [[Food and Drug Administration]] (FDA) over a ban on a drug he was using.{{cite web|url=http://www.npr.org/2013/11/01/242309799/the-dallas-cowboy-behind-the-real-buyers-club |title=The Dallas Cowboy Behind The Real 'Buyers Club' |publisher=NPR |date=2013-11-01 |accessdate=2014-07-09}} ==Biography== Woodroof was born in [[Dallas]], [[Texas]], on February 3, 1950, to Garland Odell Woodroof (March 17, 1917, in Texas - December 3, 1983, in Dallas) and Willie Mae Hughes (November 25, 1917, in [[Oklahoma]] - November 19, 1996, in Dallas).1940 United States Census: District 255-224, Family Number 207, Sheet Number and Letter 8A His first marriage was to Mary Etta Pybus on June 28, 1969, in Dallas; and they had a daughter Yvette Lynn Woodroof (born February 1, 1970). They divorced on March 23, 1972. On May 6, 1972, he married Rory S. Flynn in Dallas. They divorced on May 21, 1973. He then married Brenda Shari Robin on October 4, 1982, in [[Lubbock, Texas|Lubbock]]. They divorced on March 4, 1986, after he was diagnosed with HIV. He had a mercurial personality. One reporter writes that "Woodroof took guns to his doctor’s office, prompting Dr. Steven Pounders to 'fire him as a patient.'" Woodroof later sent the doctor roses, and the doctor took him back.{{cite web|last=Jacobson |first=Sherry |url=http://www.dallasnews.com/entertainment/movies/headlines/20131101-the-real-story-behind-the-dallas-buyers-club-movie.ece |title=The real story behind the ‘Dallas Buyers Club’ movie | Dallas Morning News |publisher=Dallasnews.com |date= |accessdate=2014-07-09}} Some of his friends told reporters he was [[gay]] or [[bisexual]].{{cite news|author=02/06/2014 3:24 pm EST |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/02/06/ron-woodroof-gay-dallas-buyers-club_n_4740155.html |title=The Real Ron Woodroof 'Had Relationships With Gay Men,' Says A Friend Of The 'Dallas Buyers Club' Subject |publisher=Huffingtonpost.com |date= February 6, 2014|accessdate=2014-07-09}}{{cite web|last=Wickman |first=Forrest |url=http://www.slate.com/blogs/browbeat/2014/01/17/was_dallas_buyers_club_s_ron_woodroof_gay_or_bisexual_friends_and_doctor.html |title=Was Dallas Buyers Club’s Ron Woodroof gay or bisexual? Friends and doctor say maybe, so why did the movie make him straight? |publisher=Slate.com |date=2014-01-17 |accessdate=2014-07-09}} Accounts differ on whether he made [[homophobic]] comments. Reporter and screenwriter [[Craig Borten]] has said Woodroof was "as [[racist]] and homophobic as they come" while friends reportedly claim the opposite. == Death and afterward == Seven years following his diagnosis of HIV, Ron Woodroof died on September 12, 1992 from [[pneumonia]] brought on by AIDS. Woodroof's final years became the basis of the 2013 film ''[[Dallas Buyers Club]].'' He was portrayed in the film by [[Matthew McConaughey]], who was critically acclaimed for his performance and won many awards, including the [[Academy Award for Best Actor]].{{cite news|title='We can't even look at him': Family of real-life AIDS victim played by Matthew McConaughey in harrowing new movie reveal the TRUE story of courage that inspired actor's 'breathtaking' transformation|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2244249/Pictured-Real-life-AIDs-victim-Ron-Woodroof-tragic-life-played-Matthew-McConaughey-movie-The-Dallas-Club.html|work=[[Daily Mail]]|accessdate=August 18, 2014|date=December 6, 2012|location=London}} ==References== {{reflist|2}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Woodroof, Ron}} [[Category:1950 births]] [[Category:1992 deaths]] [[Category:AIDS-related deaths in Texas]] [[Category:HIV/AIDS activists]] [[Category:American electricians]] [[Category:People from Dallas, Texas]]

Willie Mae Hughes (1917-1996)Social Security Death Index Number 465-18-1334 | children = }} '''Ronald Dickson Woodroof''' (February 3, 1950 – September 12, 1992) was an American man who created what would become known as the Dallas Buyer's Club[https://texashistory.unt.edu/ark%3A/67531/metadc271479/m1/2/ New Source] Dallas Buyer's Club. NEW Source, December 1991, periodical, December 1991; Dallas, Texas. (texashistory.unt.edu/ark:/67531/metadc271479/m1/2/: accessed April 16, 2018), University of North Texas Libraries, The Portal to Texas History, texashistory.unt.edu; crediting UNT Libraries Special Collections. in March 1988, one of several such [[Buyers club#AIDS epidemic|AIDS buyers clubs]] that sprang up at the time. After contracting the human immunodeficiency virus ([[HIV]]) in the 1980s, he created the group as part of his efforts to find and distribute drugs to treat HIV at a time when the disease was poorly understood.[http://www.biography.com/people/ron-woodroof-21329541 Ron Woodroof] The Biography.com website. Retrieved 2014-07-09 He sued the United States [[Food and Drug Administration]] (FDA) over a ban on [[peptide T]], a drug he was using.{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/2013/11/01/242309799/the-dallas-cowboy-behind-the-real-buyers-club |title=The Dallas Cowboy Behind The Real 'Buyers Club' |publisher=NPR |date=2013-11-01 |accessdate=2014-07-09}} Woodroof's final years became the basis of the 2013 film ''[[Dallas Buyers Club]].'' ==Biography== Woodroof was born in [[Dallas]], [[Texas]], on February 3, 1950, to Garland Odell Woodroof (March 17, 1917, in Texas - December 3, 1983, in Dallas) and Willie Mae Hughes (November 25, 1917, in [[Oklahoma]] - November 19, 1996, in Dallas).1940 United States Census: District 255-224, Family Number 207, Sheet Number and Letter 8A His first marriage was to Mary Etta Pybus on June 28, 1969, in Dallas; and they had a daughter Yvette Lynn Woodroof (born February 1, 1970). They divorced on March 23, 1972. On May 6, 1972, he married Rory S. Flynn in Dallas. They divorced on May 21, 1973. He then married Brenda Shari Robin on October 4, 1982, in [[Lubbock, Texas|Lubbock]]. They divorced on March 4, 1986, after he was diagnosed with HIV. He had a mercurial personality. One reporter writes that "Woodroof took guns to his doctor’s office, prompting Dr. Steven Pounders to 'fire him as a patient.'" Woodroof later sent the doctor roses, and the doctor took him back.{{cite web|last=Jacobson |first=Sherry |url=http://www.dallasnews.com/entertainment/movies/headlines/20131101-the-real-story-behind-the-dallas-buyers-club-movie.ece |title=The real story behind the ‘Dallas Buyers Club’ movie | Dallas Morning News |publisher=Dallasnews.com |date= |accessdate=2014-07-09}} Accounts differ on whether he made [[homophobic]] comments. Reporter and screenwriter [[Craig Borten]] has said Woodroof was "as [[racist]] and homophobic as they come" while friends reportedly claim the opposite. == Dallas Buyer's Club == After suffering from the side effects of AZT Ron Woodroof began looking for other drugs he could use to further prolong his life. He found that there were many safer drugs that were unapproved in the United States by the FDA. He began the Dallas Buyer's Club in 1988 where he would sell these drugs to other patients with AIDS that couldn't afford AZT or had bad effects from it.{{Cite news|url=http://www.slate.com/blogs/browbeat/2013/11/01/dallas_buyers_club_true_story_fact_and_fiction_in_the_matthew_mcconaughey.html|title=How Accurate Is Dallas Buyers Club?|last=Harris|first=Aisha|date=2013-11-01|work=Slate|access-date=2018-09-13|language=en-US|issn=1091-2339}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.biography.com/people/ron-woodroof-21329541|title=Ron Woodroof|website=Biography|language=en-us|access-date=2018-09-13}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.biography.com/news/dallas-buyers-club-ron-woodroof|title=‘Dallas Buyers Club’: 6 Facts on Ron Woodroof|work=Biography|access-date=2018-09-13|language=en-us}} == Death and afterward == Seven years following his diagnosis of HIV, Ron Woodroof died on September 12, 1992 from [[pneumonia]] brought on by AIDS. Woodroof's final years became the basis of the 2013 film ''[[Dallas Buyers Club]].'' He was portrayed in the film by [[Matthew McConaughey]] who won an [[Academy Award for Best Actor]] for his performance as Woodroof.{{cite news|title='We can't even look at him': Family of real-life AIDS victim played by Matthew McConaughey in harrowing new movie reveal the TRUE story of courage that inspired actor's 'breathtaking' transformation|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2244249/Pictured-Real-life-AIDs-victim-Ron-Woodroof-tragic-life-played-Matthew-McConaughey-movie-The-Dallas-Club.html|work=[[Daily Mail]]|accessdate=August 18, 2014|date=December 6, 2012|location=London}} ==References== {{Reflist|2}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Woodroof, Ron}} [[Category:1950 births]] [[Category:1992 deaths]] [[Category:AIDS-related deaths in Texas]] [[Category:HIV/AIDS activists]] [[Category:American electricians]] [[Category:People from Dallas]]
